comments.commentBody:
Mr. Kristof,

Spot on. Conflict is this region has gone on far too long. It is senseless. The civilized World has failed and we must be more dedicated to peace. Stop the gun running and convene the party's involved for talks.

I am convinced that we can do a lot more than we have. This crisis belongs to all of us.

It is time to pull out the stops and end this senseless, irrational expression. I suggested that the UN convene a conference of the mothers of the fighters and the religious leaders. No more ammo, no more weapons, no more explosives. Close the supply lines. We can do it, but we all must identify with the misery of these genetic cousins.
How lucky we are to have him in our world at this time.  He is a beacon of light when so many have none

Well, this Pope is definitely a breath of fresh air. So much different from those religious types, so common in our country. Welcome and talk to the nation about what real love means. And, I'm not even Catholic.

You are correct and -UN resolution 2625 XXV 24 Oct 1970, states, …”the free association or integration into any other political status freely determined by the people constitutes modes of implementing self-determination by that people.”
L'historian, You are quite right.

Sorry, but wars have consequences and the Falklands belong to the UK.  Who cares how far away a place is in our world of instant communications.  If distance was a factor, we "own" a number of islands in the pacific that we'd have to "set free".

El Papa was seen holding a Malvinas sign the other day and in 2012 is reported as saying, that the Falklands are Argentine and that the British had usurped the islands. He's wrong. Perhaps he should use his new iPad and Google: 'Argentina's Illegitimate Sovereignty Claims'
Not to quibble with your post, but the USA is not a democracy, and never has been.  We're a representative republic.

It the Pope's message on poverty does not include supporting birth control (which will never happen, as how else to make more Catholics?), then the Church is still the cause of much of the world's poverty.
It's almost depressing that so few people are aware of that.

"lively Democracy"..Before Citizen's United America had a democracy but afterwards with "pay to play" politics American does not have a democracy. The Pope's message on poverty and environment are incredibly important and I am sure he will do very well in America.

Though he may not mention it he may hold feelings regarding the US involvement in Latin America, and specifically Argentina, during the Cold War. The US was going after anyone that appeared a little Communist and sometimes helping the poor was enough. Pope Francis was front and center when babies and parents were being disappeared and some priests were killed for suspicious behavior. He wouldn't be human if some of those thoughts didn't linger in the back of his mind.

Socrates, I have been curious how you really look like.
Any way, your brutally honest, perhaps a bit exaggerated depiction of the United States may land on deaf ears. But every so often such attacks from within is okay. I am a naturalized American. I do not consider Americans are heartless. They have been far more charitable than many others, according to reliable statistics. And church-going Americans - means Republicans - have been more charitable than non-church attending (Democrats) ones. I consider myself a very liberal Democrat - my heroes are George McGovern, Jimmy Carter & Bill Clinton, among the politicians; people think less of Clinton, but to me he is a highly conscientious, empathetic person (Read The Natural by Joe Klein & George Stmphanopoulos's book, & a one page essay in TIME by David Gergen)

Socrates, I usually enjoy your posts, but this is politically correct nonsense!

Visit Latin America if you want to see brutality and exploitation on a terrifying scale. Francis's own country is one in which political opponents were routinely pushed out of airplanes.

Whereas the notion that American society is all about me me me is completely ridiculous. Yes, we have hedge fund managers. But most people are pretty decent, and glad to help out their neighbor.
We can't have it both ways.  If we toss our Americans in favor of new immigrants, we destroy the idea of community.

'Savage capitalism' - what an honest and heartfelt description of the United States of Unfettered Greed.

America is one of those countries where the word 'society' has never been understood...instead always preferring a childish me-me-me outlook of the universe.

Welcome to our country, Pope Francis ---- please teach the spoiled rotten adult children of the U.S. about the joys of selflessness.
Maybe in a Times editorial but not a supposedly factual news article.
there are no  quotation marks so you are praising Ms Goldstein, not the Pope;
Solid line:  "the economic giant that likes to think of itself as the center of everything."
Last time I checked, Oklahoma and Louisiana never swung a national election. Also, you need to check your voter ID as I believe you can only vote once in Texas.

Richard, I don't think the Republican party gives a damn how often a patriot votes, as long as he, or she, doesn't vote for a Democrat.

And, Grano? isn't that one o' them fru-fru organic breakfast concoctions some pinko, hippy, vegiotarian back-to-the-earther freaks shovels up from behind his pampered mule and sells in paper bags at the local "farmers" market? Hell, smoke one o' them funny, home-rolled cigarets and dog-squeezin's on ice cream is good eatin'. I can testify to that, son.

You have a nice day, now. Ya hear?

Having visited the quaint hamlet of New York City only once in my 68-and-still-counting years (well, three times, if plane changes at LaGuardia count), I find it ludicrous that any serious voter would hold Mr. Trump's hometown origins against him in the voting booth.

Why, this charming, filthy rich, cotton candy-haired, draft evading, misogynistic, racist, multi-wived, narcissist escapee from the clown car of Republican Presidents-in-waiting is just what this nation needs to re-become the greatness it never wasn't.

I most definitely will vote for Donald Trump. Twice. And that's just here in Texas. Oklahoma is only 15 minutes north, Louisiana and Arkansas just 3 hours east. Let's see, if I start in Texarkana I'll have plenty of time to make it to New Mexico and Colorado before the polls close, thanks to the time zone change. That's seven votes. Donald's worth it. And from what he tells us, a whole lot more than that.

See you at the polls.
I agree with you. I would be nervous about how he would talk with world leaders over important issues. Obama already angers some of them. Can you imagine Trump angering them more?

That a loud cartoonish buffoonish blowhard of a narcissistic phony that has built his campaign on insulting everyone and anyone while actually saying nothing of consequence about anything should at all appeal to the rightwing says more about the low state of the rightwing then about Trump himself.

Aunt Nancy:

Why are you being so kind when describing The Donald?

only a naive american would say such a thing.   i live in italy many years and your comparison is based on ignorance.  for one thing, you equate Trump's ego with Mussolini - a typical american view, based on ignorance of Italian culture, a good sized male ego is considered healthy and celebrated in italy and even respected.  Italian people hated Mussolini because he was a fascist dictator who flaunted his wealth and his mistress in the face of peasants who had nothing.  his male ego was never questioned, and definitely not in the way americans question Trump's ego.
Indeed, he does look very much like "Il Duce"
Not only does Trump look like the fascist Benito Mussolini, he talks and acts like him too!
The best thing we could do for the refugees is to make it possible for them to go home.  That means getting peace in the area somehow, so that the stream of refugees stops.

Thanks, Don!

Alternet posted my bio and linked to my blog, which includes several ways of reaching me.

I care deeply about the press in general and the Times in particular. This is all very distressing, given the polarization that already exists.

.
@ David Connell

If our author, who was 88 when this book came out, can claim to have been born on May Day, I can call my off-topic post a revolutionary act! ;-)

The rule against off-topicity is sometimes enforced, particularly against my sort. You see, I go thru life with no checkmark. It's a hard-knock life.

Anyway, Mother Jones was born in 1837. Victoria had been Queen of England for about 6 weeks. The U.S. Constitution had 12 Amendments. Darwin had not published "On the Origin of Species". The fastest way to get news from her home country (Ireland) to Canada was by ship.

In her lifetime, she lost her husband and all her children to yellow fever. The Condtitution was amended 8 more times. Poe died, 3 Presidents were assassinated, telephones and cars became widespread, and the Soviet Union was created. She hung around people like Joe Hill. "I never died" said he.

When she died, FDR was a Governor who had lost his only national election. Many silent films were still made in Hollywood. Dirigibles shared the skies with airplanes. The future Queen Elizabeth was 4 years old. And Mother Jones was famous.

She was laid to rest in a union cemetery.

And yeah, I found the Acrostic easy!

Republican and "conservative" are not synonymous. By any objective standard -- the Clinton's are a good example -- many Democrats are deeply conservative. Even the current President can be accurately described as a moderate conservative.

Nor is their anything "conservative" about the Southern strategy or the general "celebration of ignorance" which seems at the root of so much current Republican "policy".

One of the major problems in current American politics is that people who should know better keep using words that don't really mean what they would like you to think they mean.

"the country that thinks of itself as the center of everything."

Heh man, watch your nouns and what they verb. My country does not think of itself.

No, really, it is true. Trust me. Check it out for yourself. And isn't the center of this universe the Big Bang? I learned something to that effect in one of This Country's public schools. But maybe the writer had an exclusive private education, and chats with The Country were arranged by influential alumni. Or, a charter school education, learned about creationism and talking dinosaurs chatting with Adam, Noah in the ark, and, was taught The Country chatted with the forefathers about this and that. Poor thing.

Europe worked really hard during WW II to get rid of people of different backgrounds and religion.  Those who say that Europeans are only trying to protect their culture, values and religious beliefs have forgotten history.
".... unadulterated socialism." Is that worse than unadulterated capitalism?

Thomas:

I don't back off a jot or a tittle: I DO frequent West Side coffee houses, and I DO listen to the conversation. When it centers on politics rather than on which nail spot does the best job, the basic assumptions are pure socialism -- it's as if another worldview simply doesn't exist.

cec:

Unadulterated anything isn't good. But, then, nowhere in the U.S. have I heard a conversation that favored unadulterated capitalism -- not sure that one has been undertaken since Jay Gould died.

RIchard: Thank you for replying; I appreciate it. Since it's unlikely that 1% of the people in those coffeehouses know what socialism is, I'm obliged to doubt your judgement on this matter. I'm ready to change my mind if given specifics.

And I envy you your opportunity to patronize those coffeehouses and restaurants. So there!

I've spent my entire adult life either living and working in NYC, or living in NJ within 30 miles of midtown Manhattan and getting in more often than not. My first exposure to The Donald was in the late 1970s, when his lawyer was Roy Cohn (if you don't know who Roy Cohn was, do yourself and me a favor and just stop reading), two of his better friends were Al D'Amato (ditto) and George Steinbrenner, and their cavortings at Studio 54 were well-covered. I know The Donald (not personally). He has no business presenting himself as a Democrat OR a Republican, but as a Trumpian ... or perhaps merely as Trump. His ideology is self-promotion.

As to NYC outside of Manhattan these days, it remains to some extent but by no means as intensely as 40 years ago, a place of socially conservative ethnic enclaves -- a lot of people don't understand that about the city. It's one reason Bill de Blasio is so outraged at the "desnudas" in Times Square -- the bare-chested but painted female panhandlers so much a topic of current discussion.

But as regards economic ideology, and despite Wall Streeters and Rupert Murdoch, and perhaps Staten Island, NYC remains home to some of the most unchained among the liberati in this country. Sitting down in a coffee house on the Upper West Side and just listening to the conversation is an exercise in absorbing unadulterated socialism.

People seem to understand THAT; and when they start paying attention, it won't help Trump in Republican primaries.

Our involvement has been managed in a spectacularly poor manner.
Decisive action would have ended hostilities in Syria many moons ago, sparing thousands of lives. Our Nobel Peace Prize winning president has failed us miserably.

I gave up on the "Midwest" this year when the Kansas legislature managed to convince itself that taxing food was OK, but that taxing income was somehow unAmerican. If that's the kind of thinking which comes from a modern Midwest background, then we can clearly do without it.

And I'm pretty sure that Eisenhower would agree with me.

I believe that the Democrats had a political monopoly just 6 years ago. The observation that a revenue neutral carbon tax wasn't even on the table says a lot more about political power being far more important to the political class than actually solving the excess CO2 problem.

A cap and trade with existing cronies getting free goodies and outsiders getting more bureaucratic rulers was much more to their liking.

Imagine how fracking and associated natural gas power plant would have evolved under "cap and trade as proposed". These new sources, which are low carbon, not carbon free, would have to pay full fare on the trade market for any carbon credits given for free or reduced costs to the existing carbon polluters.

The Democrats had a political monopoly for exactly 7 months in 2009. From Jan 2009 until August 2009 they had 60 votes in the senate to avoid republican filibuster. Yes they should have taken advantage of that time, but they were too focused on healthcare reform. After August 2009, they needed to win over at least one republican to pass climate legislation and there was no chance of that happening.

Unfortunately even Waxman-Markey, aka cap and trade, which was heavily altered to try to win bi-paritisan support (and was originally a republican idea) got only 8 republican votes in the house, and would have gotten none in the senate.

So fault here if any was that the Democrats tried to compromise too much to get a deal.

I agree that a Carbon Tax is the best way to take action on climate change, and that in the end, it will be Republicans who will pass some sort of climate legislation. But, Mankiw is clearly wrong to blame Democrats when the overwhelming opposition to action has come from Republicans. I mean when was the last time a Republican in congress expressed supported for reducing CO2 emissions?

The vast majority of Democrats would vote for a revenue-neutral tax, while Republicans choose James Inhofe – a climate denier of the worst kind – to be their voice as the chairman of the Senate Environment Committee. The problem is that taxes of any kind, and government involvement to solve large problems are the antithesis of the modern republican party. This is a party which no longer believes in the ideas championed by an old-school conservative like Mankiw. Its a party of radical right wing ideologues who deny there is a climate problem to suit their needs, and those of their benefactors like the oil & gas industry.

Yes climate legislation will only happen when Republicans support it - only because they are the road block to an agreement. And while a revenue-neutral carbon tax is the best alternative, only one party is willing to pass such legislation (Democrats). Finally, Mankiw clearly isn't accepting the reality about how far the Republican party has shifted to the right. He is still stuck in the aura of a moderate republican party that hasn't existed in 40 years.
Ah, but it was painted, not drowned.
Does Michelangelo's first Pieta require explanation?

DJT I admit I like. He talks his beliefs, and I think he has as much right to change them as anyone. I expect he has read the news on Germany today, and as I celebrate it, I wonder if Donald might feel he may have been led by the nose down the wrong path regarding the position he has taken on building the wall. I like his idea that it should be done, and done well, but with a big welcome gate at every legal entry like the one you New Yorker's had at Ellis Island.

I lived in Marianna, a small little mining town in southwest Pennsylvania. Just outside town lies a large Russian Orthodox cemetery dating from the 1800s. When Bethlehem Steel executives heard of the mass immigration of Russian families exiting Czarist Russia for Ellis Island, it sent a team of representatives to the island with only one marching order. I paraphrase: "If you see a Russian family get off any boat or ship, offer them a train ticket to Pittsburgh and a home in Marianna and a lifetime job."

Needless to say, I was proud to meet many of the descendants of these Russian immigrants.

As a 10th generation American of German extraction, I salute the German nation today, and I welcome the possibility that Donald and Hilary and all the other presidential candidates will revisit the immigration issue with an open mind.

All New Yorkers should all understand this as well as anyone on the planet! If New York isn't the melting pot, where the heck is it?

The Bush clan are New Englanders… Connecticut and Maine. Yale educated for the most part. Some adopted Texas because of the oil money.
Dubya the tinhorn faux-cowpoke was, and remains, a posturing fake. "Clearing brush" like another fake cowboy, Ronald Reagan the bad B-picture actor.
